      <title>FA Cup fifth round: Rochdale v Tottenham Hotspur – live!</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/18/fa-cup-rochdale-v-tottenham-hotspur-live</link>
      <description><ul><li>Minute-by-minute updates from the 4pm GMT kick-off</li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ian-henderson-rochdale-spurs-fa-cup">Ian Henderson: ‘In Turkey I didn’t get paid. I was my own lawyer’</a></li><li>And feel free to <a href="mailto:nick.ames.casual@theguardian.com">mail Nick</a> or tweet <a href="https://twitter.com/NickAmes82">@NickAmes82</a> to get in touch<br></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-18T16:47:56.409Z">4.47pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><strong>What a game we have on now. </strong>I was about to type that it had been a genuinely end-to-end, decent cup tie with no obvious winner before Henderson scored. Then he did, and anything could happen now. As at Newport, Spurs have a real problem now – but Rochdale are better than Newport. Are we on the verge of something historic? Will Harry Kane get an early call? We’ll find out soon!</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-18T16:46:48.287Z">4.46pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>How about that? The goal is the half’s last real action!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/18/fa-cup-rochdale-v-tottenham-hotspur-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Russian athlete reportedly fails Winter Olympics drugs test</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/winter-olympics-russian-athlete-reportedly-fails-drugs-test</link>
      <description>• OAR confirm ‘possible violation of anti-doping rules’<br />• IOC banned Russia from Pyeongchang over doping<p>A Russian athlete who won a bronze medal in the mixed curling at the Winter Olympics has reportedly failed a drugs test. Reports in the Russian newspaper Sport Express suggested the male curler, Alexander Krushelnytsky, had been found with meldonium in his urine.</p><p>If the news is confirmed, the Olympic Athletes from Russia could be stripped of the bronze medal won by Krushelnytsky, alongside his wife, Anastasia Bryzgalovoy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/winter-olympics-russian-athlete-reportedly-fails-drugs-test">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Twenty20 internationals should be abolished, says England’s Trevor Bayliss</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/twenty-20-internationals-abolished-trevor-bayliss</link>
      <description>• England coach concerned about exhausting schedule<br />• ‘I’d just let the franchises play. There’ll be blowout’<p>Trevor Bayliss used his post-match debrief to call for an end to international Twenty20 matches. Speaking after England had secured a two-run win over New Zealand, their first of the Trans-Tasman Tri-Series but one that was not enough to take them into the final against Australia, the coach said a rethink is in order, for the sake of the schedule and those involved.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/england-new-zealand-tri-series-twenty20-match-report">England miss out on T20 tri-series final despite narrow win over New Zealand</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/twenty-20-internationals-abolished-trevor-bayliss">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The unequal battle: privilege, genes, gender and power | @Anna_Kessel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power</link>
      <description><p>The tense debate around Caster Semenya and Dutee Chand demonstrate the intersection between race, gender and medical imperialism</p><p>When I was eight years old I visited South Africa, my dad’s homeland, for the first time. I’ll never forget flying into Jo’burg, looking down over the houses in the city and seeing hundreds of turquoise squiggles and dots. “Wow,” I said, excitedly, “everyone has a swimming pool here!”<br></p><p>My dad gave me a stern look. “Not everyone,” he said. It was 1987 and apartheid was in its final throes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Timm Klose gives Norwich a point in dramatic finish against Ipswich</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/norwich-city-ipswich-town-championship-match-report</link>
      <description><p>It was like the harvest festival and the summer equinox came all at once. A see-saw end to the Old Farm derby sent first one set of fans then the other into delirium as two late goals meant the spoils were shared between Norwich and Ipswich.</p><p>First Luke Chambers for Ipswich then, in the final seconds of added time, Timm Klose for Norwich scored thumping headers in a contest that swung first one way then the other and ultimately ended in a draw. It also means City remain unbeaten in 10 derby matches.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/norwich-city-ipswich-town-championship-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Groves beats Chris Eubank Jr on points despite shoulder injury drama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/george-groves-chris-eubank-jr-fight-report</link>
      <description><p>• Groves sees out last round with one arm immobilised<br>• Londoner into World Boxing Super Series final after brutal fight</p><p>George Groves finished a wild night in Manchester with his left arm hanging redundantly by his side, his WBA super-middleweight title intact, a cheque for £1.6m safely lodged and the prospect of more to come in the final of the World Boxing Super Series in London on 2 June.</p><p>Chris Eubank Jr, cruelly, went home to Brighton with nothing but a significant blood deficit from gaping cuts across his features and the acknowledgment of a capacity crowd whose jeers turned to cheers after his full-throttle effort to blow the Londoner out of the ring over 12 rounds. It was little comfort, although they might do it all again once this tournament is over. Groves now awaits the winner of next weekend’s semi-final in Nuremberg between the unbeaten Liverpudlian Callum Smith and Jürgen Brähmer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/george-groves-chris-eubank-jr-fight-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Odds fixed against betters at racecourses, claims bookmaker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/odds-fixed-against-novice-betters-bookmakers</link>
      <description>• Andy Smith says fellow bookmakers target inovice gamblers<br />• Ffos Las in Wales last August offered notably poor odds<p>Racecourse bookmakers collude to rip-off punters, according to a sensational claim by one of their number this week. Andy Smith, who takes bets as ‘Festival Racing’ and is known for his outspoken views, said bookies sometimes agree before racing starts they will build a particularly big profit margin into their odds, especially when a large crowd of inexperienced gamblers is expected.</p><p>Smith’s comments were prompted by a survey published recently <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/waiting-patiently-cue-card-ascot-chase-ruth-jefferson-colin-tizzard" title="">by the Horseracing Bettors</a> Forum, which showed odds offered at the Welsh racetrack Ffos Las were notably poor last year, most obviously on 25 August. That was the fixture marketed as ‘Ladies’ Day’, when the track had its biggest attendance of the year, at around 6,000 people.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/odds-fixed-against-novice-betters-bookmakers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hakan Sukur – Turkey’s fallen hero who can never return home</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/hakan-sukur-turkey-fallen-hero-exile</link>
      <description>Scorer of the fastest World Cup goal had Turkey’s president as a wedding guest but now lives in enforced exile in the US<p>There is a photograph, famous in Turkey, taken at the wedding of one of the nation’s greatest footballers, a Uefa Cup winner who played in a World Cup semi-final. In the picture, Hakan Sukur is next to two witnesses, the nation’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and the cleric Fethullah Gulen. A wedding is supposed to be one of the highlights in a man’s life but it did not work out like that for Sukur.</p><p>The woman he married that day is dead, Sukur’s father has been imprisoned and the player capped 112 times by Turkey finds himself in exile. Should he ever return to his native land he would face charges of insulting the president and rebelling against the government. Life imprisonment would be certain and he could even face the death penalty. He will never see his father again, all the adulation he once had is lost. Sukur has lost his country.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/hakan-sukur-turkey-fallen-hero-exile">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/turkey">Turkey</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/football">Football</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/sport">Sport</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/turkey-coup-attempt">Turkey coup attempt</category>
      <pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 08:01:38 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/hakan-sukur-turkey-fallen-hero-exile</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4389af38aaa1e73baa5f9592f1aee6c7ecb3865a/0_85_2048_1229/master/2048.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=48f589fa057f79d361bc12e33666d47b">

    <item>
      <title>England miss out on T20 tri-series final despite narrow win over New Zealand</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/england-new-zealand-tri-series-twenty20-match-report</link>
      <description>• New Zealand 192-4, England 194-7; England win by two runs<br />• Black Caps seal final against Australia after passing 174 runs<p>A match that summed up England’s disastrous Trans-Tasman tri-series saw victory sealed off the final ball but the game effectively lost 11 deliveries earlier. Needing to beat New Zealand by 20 runs to qualify for the tri-series final, their two-run win, as thrilling as it might have been in any other context, was thoroughly underwhelming. New Zealand will now face Australia in Wednesday’s final at Auckland.</p><p>The team analyst crunched the numbers and after double-checking with the bods at Loughborough overnight, confirmed to Eoin Morgan that victory by around 20 runs – or achieving a target with two or three overs to spare – would see them go through. At the halfway stage, having posted 194 for seven, England had their answer – they needed to keep the Black Caps to 174 or below.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/england-new-zealand-tri-series-twenty20-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/devante-smith-pelly-chicago-blackhawks-racist-taunts</link>
      <description><ul><li>Fans shouted ‘basketball, basketball, basketball’ at player</li><li>Canadian has spoken of loneliness of being a hockey player </li></ul><p>Devante Smith-Pelly was taunted by four fans shouting “basketball, basketball, basketball” on Saturday night during the Chicago Blackhawks’ game against the Washington Capitals.</p><p>Washington’s Smith-Pelly, who is black, was serving a major penalty for fighting Chicago’s Connor Murphy when the fans taunted him in the penalty box. An off-ice official sitting next to him notified building security, and the fans were ejected. Smith-Pelly was visibly upset by the taunting, at one point tapping the glass separating him from the fans.&nbsp;</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/devante-smith-pelly-chicago-blackhawks-racist-taunts">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Wales’ Ken Owens says Warren Gatland deserves more respect</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/wales-ken-owens-warren-gatland-respect-six-nations</link>
      <description><p>• ‘I don’t think he gets the credit for what he has achieved’<br>• Wales must beat Ireland in Dublin to stay in Six Nations hunt</p><p>Ken Owens believes Warren Gatland’s sustained success at Test level has not always gained the respect the coach’s record merits. Gatland takes charge of Wales for the 100th time on Saturday in Ireland, where his international coaching career started in 1998, but the Lions hooker says: “I don’t think he gets the credit for what he has achieved.”</p><p>“Inside and outside Wales he has always had to, for some reason, prove himself,” says Owens <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/jun/27/warren-gatland-clown-second-time-new-zealand-lions-tour" title="">as unflattering portraits</a> of Gatland in New Zealand during last year’s Lions tour showed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/wales-ken-owens-warren-gatland-respect-six-nations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/great-britains-woods-falls-agonisingly-short-in-ski-slopestyle</link>
      <description><ul><li>Beaulieu-Marchand took bronze 1.4 points ahead of Woods</li><li>26-year-old Briton suffered whiplash and needed stitches</li></ul><p>Great Britain’s James Woods suffered whiplash and needed stitches after a series of spectacular performances in the ski slopestyle – but suffered more agony when he missed out on bronze at the death.<br><br>Woods, 26, was in third with only five skiers remaining in the final and looked set to join Izzy Atkin in securing a second British ski medal in Pyeongchang only for the American Nick Goepper to pip him on his final run.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/adam-rippon-figure-skating-winter-olympics">This charming Olympian Adam Rippon deserves another medal | Rebecca Nicholson</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/great-britains-woods-falls-agonisingly-short-in-ski-slopestyle">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>• Froome welcomes diversion from controversy before fourth stage <br />• Late puncture puts British rider out of contention; he slips to 14th<p>Chris Froome has faced a grilling at every juncture of a race overtaken by debate around his involvement. The start of the penultimate stage of the Ruta del Sol was no different but this time it was Tim from Cheltenham asking the questions and he had little interest in discussing salbutamol.</p><p>With the grand central building of Seville’s Plaza de España behind him, Froome had his game face on, exchanging a few words with his team-mate Philip Deignan until Tim leaned over the metal barrier to employ the four-times Tour de France winner as his own personal travel guide.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/chris-froome-respite-from-controversy-ruta-del-sol-puncture-cycling">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Matt Toomua’s try turns game Leicester’s way against Harlequins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/leicester-harlequins-premiership-match-report</link>
      <description>• Leicester 33-18 Harlequins<br />• Toomua sprinted 25 metres to line after a dummy<p>It was the 20th anniversary of the sacking of Bob Dwyer as Leicester’s director of rugby and there was a point in the second half when it seemed his compatriot Matt O’Connor was in danger of suffering the same fate. The Tigers were heading for their 11th defeat in 12 league and European Cup matches when another Australian, Matt Toomua, who started at outside-half, transformed the match.</p><p>Little went for him in the opening 58 minutes when the creaking Tigers were fortunate to trail only 13-9 but, when he spotted Kyle Sinckler opposite him at a ruck, he dummied the prop and sprinted 25 metres to the line. Three minutes later his chip bounced kindly for Sione Kalamafoni on Quins’ 22 and, when the No&nbsp;8 was brought down, the second row Graham Kitchener was in support and in effect sealed Leicester’s second Premiership victory in three months.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/leicester-harlequins-premiership-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Waiting Patiently impresses with emotional win over Cue Card in Ascot Chase</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/waiting-patiently-cue-card-ascot-chase-ruth-jefferson-colin-tizzard</link>
      <description>• Ruth Jefferson may bypass Cheltenham with stable star<br />• Colin Tizzard thrilled with back to form Cue Card<p>Good-news stories abounded here, as Waiting Patiently won the Ascot Chase for his new trainer, Ruth Jefferson, on the day after she said a final farewell to her father. Cue Card ran a mighty race to be second and will take his chance at the Cheltenham Festival once more, while Bryony Frost continued her amazing run of Saturday successes by landing the Reynoldstown on her beloved Black Corton.</p><p>Emotion was running high. Frost came close to tears, as did Colin Tizzard, vindicated in his view that Cue Card is still a top-class chaser at the age of 12. But Jefferson kept her cool, even as she became perhaps the first trainer ever to land a Grade One only two days after her first winner.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/waiting-patiently-cue-card-ascot-chase-ruth-jefferson-colin-tizzard">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>FA Cup quarter-final draw - Leicester to face Chelsea, Man Utd draw Brighton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/fa-cup-quarter-final-draw-live</link>
      <description><p>Leicester will host Chelsea in the last eight of the FA Cup, while Brighton will face Manchester United and Sheffield Wednesday could host Tottenham</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T21:35:36.575Z">9.35pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Manchester United were drawn at home to Brighton in an FA Cup quarter-final draw which saw all the big guns avoid each other on Saturday evening. </p><p>Jose Mourinho’s men learned they would face the Seagulls shortly after sealing their place in the last eight with a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report">2-0 fifth-round win at Huddersfield</a> thanks to Romelu Lukaku’s brace. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T20:10:24.616Z">8.10pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><strong>If everything goes with the form book</strong> then we should be looking at Chelsea, Manchester United, Manchester City and Spurs in the semi-final. The FA Cup is rarely that simple, so we should end up with an upset or two, if we are lucky.</p><p>We do get a repeat of the 1983 FA Cup final when Manchester United host Brighton but other than that it looks like it could be a quiet round. Only time will tell, though.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/fa-cup-quarter-final-draw-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Elise Christie hopeful of competing in 1000m short-track despite injury</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/christie-in-doubt-for-1000m-speed-skating-heats-with-ankle-damage</link>
      <description><ul><li>Christie has had two high-speed crashes at the Games</li><li>27-year-old has soft tissue damage in her right ankle</li></ul><p>Elise Christie will decide at the last minute whether to risk racing in Tuesday’s 1000m heats after sustaining soft tissue damage in her right ankle in a dramatic crash that led to her being stretchered off the track.</p><p>A subsequent hospital scan showed that there were no broken bones, and British Olympic chiefs also insist that the 27-year-old has no mental scars despite her second high-speed smash of these Winter Olympics.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/christie-in-doubt-for-1000m-speed-skating-heats-with-ankle-damage">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gus Kenworthy's kiss with boyfriend on NBC greeted with acclaim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics</link>
      <description><p>The British-born American freestyle skier failed to add to his silver from Sochi, but a historic kiss with his boyfriend on primetime network TV may have made an even bigger impact back home</p><p>When the American freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy shared a kiss with boyfriend Matthew Wilkas at the bottom of the hill before Sunday morning’s ski slopestyle qualifying, neither was immediately aware the moment was captured by NBC’s cameras.</p><p>But the significance of an openly gay male athlete kissing another man on primetime network television during one of the world’s biggest collective experiences was not lost on the Saturday night audience back home in the United States where it quickly went viral and was feted by LGBT activists as a marker of progress amid the <a href="https://www.outsports.com/2018/2/9/16997928/nbc-winter-olympics-lgbt-opening-ceremony">broadcaster’s much-criticized handling</a> of gay athletes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eddie Jones enforces ‘never stand still’ credo in brutal week for England</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/eddie-jones-england-six-nations-brutal-training-week</link>
      <description>Squad were put through an intense week of scrum, lineout and fitness work in preparation for the Calcutta Cup match in Scotland<p>The England squad’s reward for two victories in the opening rounds of the Six Nations was a brutal training week, starting with set-piece sessions against scrum-savouring Georgia and finishing with a high-intensity run-out at Twickenham in front of 10,000 spectators.</p><p>“Never stand still” is the motto of the head coach, Eddie Jones, and while summoning Georgia for a full-on scrum and lineout exchange could be cited as evidence of where the champions intend to target Scotland at Murrayfield on Saturday, the area they know they have to control is the breakdown. The fewer mistakes they make, the greater the chance of an eighth successive Calcutta Cup win.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/eddie-jones-england-six-nations-brutal-training-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>The Edinburgh tighthead wants to help turn the tables at Murrayfield after last year’s humiliation at Twickenham<p>Christchurch may be the most English of New Zealand’s cities but Simon Berghan, when he was growing up there, was always aware of being on the other side when it came to the Calcutta Cup.     <item>
      <title>Ian Henderson: ‘In Turkey I didn’t get paid. I was acting as my own lawyer’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ian-henderson-rochdale-spurs-fa-cup</link>
      <description><p>Bad luck and instability almost led Rochdale’s captain to quit football. Now he has found a happy place and has Spurs in his sights</p><p>Ian Henderson had reached a crossroads in his life when the invitation came to train with Rochdale five years ago. He had just been released by Colchester United and the realities of life as a professional footballer were not turning out to be what he had envisaged when he was coming through the youth system at Norwich City. Being offered bags of cash by persons unknown to leave the Turkish club Ankaragucu in 2009 had seen to that.</p><p>Clubless and careerless, or so he thought, the striker considered turning his back on football to become an orthodontist. Today, as captain of Rochdale in the FA Cup fifth round, it is only the lilywhites of Tottenham Hotspur that concern him. Today he will feel indebted to the manager, Keith Hill, for providing the right direction.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ian-henderson-rochdale-spurs-fa-cup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Valverde’s Barcelona balancing act turns crisis talk to treble talk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ernesto-valverde-barcelona-crisis-treble-chelsea-champions-league</link>
      <description>The coach used Neymar’s exit as a chance to reboot the faltering giants as Chelsea may find out on Tuesday<p>Sometimes football really is life. On Tuesday Barcelona face Chelsea in the Champions League at Stamford Bridge where in 2009 Andrés Iniesta scored a last-minute goal that he still watches occasionally. “It’s a moment that is always there, forever,” he says. For some fans, reminded of it daily, that is especially true. According to a spokeswoman for the maternity ward at the Quirón hospital in Catalonia, his goal didn’t only take Barça to the final, it provoked a spike in the birth rate. “I’m going to have to get more staff in if they keep winning titles,” Mercedes Rodríguez joked.</p><p>Nine months after Iniesta’s goal, Rodríguez noted that births were up from nine or 10 a day to 14 or 15 in her hospital alone. “People asked if there had been a full moon or something,” she said. Some reports claimed a 45% increase, which seemed unlikely, so it was tested. A study in the British Medical Journal admitted to potential “bias owing to the effects of the adjacent jubilation” of Barcelona-supporting researchers and was quick to note that they “didn’t contribute to the observed effect”, but tentatively concluded that it was plausible to talk of a 16% rise. More research, though, was needed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ernesto-valverde-barcelona-crisis-treble-chelsea-champions-league">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>José Mourinho: VAR ‘went against original protocol’ to rule out Mata goal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/var-jose-mourinho-manchester-united-fa-cup-huddersfield</link>
      <description>• Video official was deployed to judge Juan Mata offside<br />• Lines on the screen appeared to be wavy and uneven<p>José Mourinho said that the use of VAR to disallow a Juan Mata goal in Manchester United’s 2-0 FA Cup fifth round win over Hudderfield Town “went against the original protocol” of the system and that football is “ too beautiful to be spoiled by something not perfect.”</p><p>Mata was initially adjudged to have beaten the offside trap to score in the first-half, but the decision was referred to the video referee and he was deemed to be beyond the last man - or, at least, his knee was slightly beyond the offside line.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/var-jose-mourinho-manchester-united-fa-cup-huddersfield">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jupp Heynckes, the safe pair of hands Bayern Munich can’t bear to lose</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/jupp-heynckes-bayern-munich-safe-pair-of-hands-desperate-to-stay</link>
      <description>Instead of just minding the shop in his fourth stint as manager the man from Mönchengladbach is being begged to stay<p>Jupp Heynckes has a proud record to protect. In each of the three seasons he has coached a team in the Champions League, they have reached the final. And should Bayern Munich win this season’s competition – a quest that continues with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/champions-league-last-16-fans-preview" title="">Tuesday’s first-leg meeting with Beskitas</a> – he is likely to repeat what followed his two victories: swiftly departing the club he guided to Europe’s premier prize.</p><p>In 1998, Real Madrid sacked him despite a first European Cup in 32 years, while in 2013 Bayern had already agreed to bring Pep Guardiola to Bavaria. Having beaten Borussia Dortmund 2-1 at Wembley, Heynckes somewhat reluctantly entered a retirement that lasted until September’s return as a sprightly 72-year-old.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/jupp-heynckes-bayern-munich-safe-pair-of-hands-desperate-to-stay">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/antonio-conte-chelsea-perfect-game-barcelona-champions-league</link>
      <description>• Manager seeks to exploit ‘weaknesses without the ball’ <br />• Cesc Fàbregas to forget old friendships on pitch<p>Antonio Conte insists Barcelona are not infallible and that it would be dangerous for his rejuvenated team to focus solely on stopping Lionel Messi – who has never scored against Chelsea – when the two sides meet at Stamford Bridge on Tuesday evening.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/16/eden-hazard-chelsea-barcelona-messi-champions-league" title="">Chelsea host Ernesto Valverde’s side</a> in the first leg of the Champions League last-16 for the first time since beating the La Liga leaders in the semi-finals of the competition in 2012, the same year they went on to lift the trophy after edging out Bayern Munich on penalties.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/antonio-conte-chelsea-perfect-game-barcelona-champions-league">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/fulham-aston-villa-championship-match-report</link>
      <description><p>Ryan Sessegnon does not turn 18 until May, by which point Fulham could well be, on this evidence at least, celebrating their return to the Premier League. Sessegnon’s seventh goal in eight matches kick-started an impressive victory over Aston Villa before Floyd Ayité’s stunning effort from the halfway line after an error by the goalkeeper, Sam Johnstone, ensured the visitors’ seven-match winning run came to a grinding halt by the Thames.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/leicester-sheffield-united-fa-cup-match-report">Jamie Vardy strike enough for Leicester to see off Sheffield United</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/fulham-aston-villa-championship-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>For Brighton this win brought a quarter-final place for the first time since 1986 and the suggestion Chris Hughton finally has the depth at his disposal to combine a tilt at the FA Cup and a successful relegation fight.</p><p>For Coventry the battle remains yet more profound; Mark Robins’s League Two side were well beaten but it must be hoped that, as a minimum, such an engaging run has propelled a famous, deeply troubled old name back into the national consciousness for good.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/brighton-coventry-city-fa-cup-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Manchester United’s Romelu Lukaku sinks Huddersfield despite VAR chaos</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report</link>
      <description><p>Paul Pogba missed this game through illness, leaving Manchester United to book their place in the last eight of the FA Cup without him. Thanks to Romelu Lukaku’s 20th and 21st goals of the season they managed it comfortably enough, the striker showing the value of possessing an accomplished goalscorer when chances are few and far between.</p><p>Huddersfield could have done with a similarly potent spearhead, since for all their attacking intent they came up short in front of goal. With the benefit of an early lead United could afford to be economical, letting their opponents have most of the ball and hitting them effectively on the counter. The visitors were not at their swaggering best, yet the home side ended up grateful to a VAR call at the end of the first half for helping keep the scoreline respectable. “We didn’t get the result we wanted but confidence wise we are going in the right direction,” David Wagner said. “We are building up momentum again.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: John Peters/Man Utd via Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/660d96ec80d1b3b1c393dbe08d50682c6d27a3de/205_0_2652_1591/master/2652.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=99af827af74a7e0fce12691722a85c46">

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/video/2018/feb/08/the-yorkshire-connection-team-gb-ski-and-snowboard-winter-olympics-medal-hopefuls-video</link>
      <description><p>Jamie Nicholls and Katie Summerhayes have something in common beyond making Team GB for Pyeongchang 2018, they grew up on the dry ski slopes across Yorkshire. Aside from providing a further two athletes for the 2018 ski team, the Yorkshire scene has produced a slew of World Cup medals.     <item>
      <title>Sports quiz of the week: Winter Olympics, history, goals and disrespect</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/16/sports-quiz-week-winter-olympics-champions-league-disrespect</link>
      <description><p>Who conceded? Who coached? And who was ‘a bit chubby’?</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/15/spot-the-sport-take-our-winter-olympics-picture-quiz">Spot the sport – take our Winter Olympics picture quiz</a> </p><p class="question__text">Pita Taufatofua is competing in the 15km cross-country event at the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. In which event did the Tongan compete at the Rio Olympics in 2016?</p><p class="answer__text">Marathon</p><p class="answer__text">Taekwondo</p><p class="answer__text">Rugby 7s </p><p class="answer__text">Shot put </p><p class="question__text">Which football team conceded a goal this week for the first time in 2018?</p><p class="answer__text">Fulham</p><p class="answer__text">Juventus </p><p class="answer__text">Bayern Munich </p><p class="answer__text">Celtic</p><p class="question__text">How did British bobsleigh driver Toby Olubi help fund his training for the Winter Olympics?</p><p class="answer__text">He sold vacuum cleaners door to door in Camberwell </p><p class="answer__text">He played the role of a hyena in a production of The Lion King </p><p class="answer__text">He won £12,000 on Deal or No Deal</p><p class="answer__text">He made £30m trading Bitcoin </p><p class="question__text">How did Eric Radford make history in Pyeongchang?</p><p class="answer__text">He became the first athlete to win two gold medals for different countries </p><p class="answer__text">He became the first Monegasque athlete to win an Olympic medal </p><p class="answer__text">He became the first openly gay male gold medalist in Winter Olympics history </p><p class="answer__text">He became the first ever athlete from the Isle of Man to win a gold medal</p><p class="question__text">How are the Finland team enjoying their down time at the Winter Olympics? </p><p class="answer__text">Riding up escalators on their skis </p><p class="answer__text">Knitting a blanket for the Finnish president’s newborn son</p><p class="answer__text">Holding up “funny” banners at events where Swedish athletes are competing </p><p class="answer__text">Dressing up as the Pyeongchang mascots, Soohorang and Bandabi </p><p class="question__text">Which footballer – who was released by Arsenal as an eight-year-old – was the club’s former academy director, Liam Brady, talking about when he said: “He was a bit chubby and he wasn’t very athletic, but we made a mistake”?</p><p class="answer__text">Cristiano Ronaldo </p><p class="answer__text">Wayne Rooney </p><p class="answer__text">Dele Alli </p><p class="answer__text">Harry Kane</p><p class="question__text">Who said: “I am fully committed to win the award this season of the best behaved manager on the touchline”?</p><p class="answer__text">Eddie Jones </p><p class="answer__text">Warren Gatland </p><p class="answer__text">José Mourinho </p><p class="answer__text">Jürgen Klopp </p><p class="question__text">Who set up Philippe Coutinho to score his first goal for Barcelona?</p><p class="answer__text">His brother-in-law </p><p class="answer__text">His international captain </p><p class="answer__text">His best friend from primary school </p><p class="answer__text">The same player who set up his first goal for Liverpool</p><p class="question__text">Where did Wigan Warriors beat Hull FC?</p><p class="answer__text">Warsaw</p><p class="answer__text">Washington</p><p class="answer__text">Wellington</p><p class="answer__text">Wollongong</p><p class="question__text">Why did a few Phoenix Suns players call Golden State Warriors coach Steve Kerr “disrespectful” after their NBA match?</p><p class="answer__text">He had fallen asleep during the game </p><p class="answer__text">He ate a large bag of popcorn in the fourth quarter</p><p class="answer__text">He had let his players coach themselves</p><p class="answer__text">He was spotted updating his Fantasy Football team on his phone</p><p class="score__min-score">1 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Dire</p><p class="score__min-score">2 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Shocking</p><p class="score__min-score">3 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Shocking</p><p class="score__min-score">4 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You've slipped up there</p><p class="score__min-score">5 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Halfway there</p><p class="score__min-score">6 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Decent</p><p class="score__min-score">7 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Impressive</p><p class="score__min-score">8 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Nice work. Enjoy your weekend</p><p class="score__min-score">9 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Fantastic work. Enjoy your weekend</p><p class="score__min-score">0 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Dire</p><p class="score__min-score">10 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You are a genius.       <description><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2016/jan/05/the-fiver-email-sign-up">Sign up now</a>! <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2016/jan/05/the-fiver-email-sign-up">Sign up now</a>! <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2016/jan/05/the-fiver-email-sign-up">Sign up now</a>? <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2016/jan/05/the-fiver-email-sign-up">Sign up now</a>!</p><p>Just over five years have elapsed since Southampton responded to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/16/chelsea-southampton-premier-league">a sorry little 2-2 draw with Chelsea</a> at Stamford Bridge by telling Nigel Adkins that his services were no longer required and replacing him with an obscure foreign man who went by the name of something like Manuel or Marco, sparking an outpouring of rage in the British media. The guy couldn’t even speak English! Imagine! What on earth were they thinking?       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/football-transfer-rumours-manchester-uniteds-paul-pogba-to-real-madrid</link>
      <description><p>Today’s fluff just toss that ham in the fryin’ pan</p><p>In devastating news for <strong>Manchester United</strong> fans, it seems that one of their top midfielders is likely to leave this summer. Get the emotional tributes ready as soon as possible because there are reports in Turkey that <strong>Marouane Fellaini</strong> has agreed a contract with <strong>Besiktas</strong>. Don’t all cry at once. Oh, and <strong>Paul Pogba</strong> is also off. The Frenchman will join <strong>Real Madrid</strong> for £120m after deciding that José Mourinho ain’t worth it. United will console themselves by signing <strong>Mauro Icardi</strong> from <strong>Internazionale</strong>. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/tottenham-erik-lamela-contract-extend">Tottenham have option to extend Érik Lamela’s contract by a further year</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/football-transfer-rumours-manchester-uniteds-paul-pogba-to-real-madrid">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Precedent is everything in the murky, confused world of TMO decisions</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/15/tmo-decision-wales-england-precedent-six-nations</link>
      <description>The rumbling row over the decision not to award a try to Wales’s Gareth Anscombe against England highlights another grey area in the game’s laws<p>Warren Gatland decried a “terrible mistake” by the TMO after Wales’s defeat to England last weekend and prompted an admission from World Rugby that the law had not been properly applied when <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/13/world-rugby-gareth-anscombe-try-wales">Gareth Anscombe beat Anthony Watson to the ball</a> over England’s line at Twickenham.</p><p>The television match official Glenn Newman ruled that Anscombe had not properly grounded the ball before Watson did but after reviewing the 24th-minute incident World Rugby, whose head of referees, Alain Rolland, had spoken to Gatland, ruled that “in accordance with law 21.1b Wales should have been awarded a try as the Wales player grounded the ball”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/15/tmo-decision-wales-england-precedent-six-nations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/footballers-joining-and-leaving-a-club-in-the-same-transfer-window-the-knowledge</link>
      <description><p>Plus: extreme weather at the very first MLS Cup and winning the FA Cup the hard way. <a href="mailto:knowledge@theguardian.com">Mail us your questions and answers</a> or tweet <a href="https://twitter.com/theknowledge_gu">@TheKnowledge_GU</a></p><p><strong>“Scott Bain signed for Hibs on loan on the first day of the window and left for Celtic on the last day. Have any other players ever joined and left a club in the same window?”</strong> tweets Brian Milne.</p><p>The answer, of course, is yes. In the summer of 1980, Clive Allen joined Arsenal from QPR for a fee of £1.25m. He played in three friendlies before joining Crystal Palace’s team of the 80s, in a swap deal which sent Kenny Sansom and his Norman Wisdom impressions in the opposite direction. Ostend Gudgeon reckons this became a Newman-Baddiel running gag, “probably in the Mary Whitehouse Experience”. <br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/footballers-joining-and-leaving-a-club-in-the-same-transfer-window-the-knowledge">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘It isn’t easy admitting you were one of Barry Bennell’s boys’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/crewe-barry-bennell-micky-fallon</link>
      <description><p>Micky Fallon, one of the former players Bennell has been convicted of abusing, reveals the horrors he endured and asks how Crewe did not realise the coach was a risk when opponents called them ‘The paedophile lads’</p><p>There is a scar on my cheek that will always be there to remind me about my childhood. Over the years, I’ve got used to it being there, I suppose. But whenever anyone asked how I got that scar I would just say as little as possible and move on swiftly. It was easier that way because, if I said what really happened, that would mean explaining I used to be at Crewe Alexandra. I knew if I said those words I’d have to get my head in a space that took me back to that football club. And from the age of 18, since the day I left that club, I’d shut down that part of my life off and, until now, never wanted to revisit it.</p><p>The truth is not easy for me to explain. For 32 years, I denied everything. I read <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/16/andy-woodward">the interview with Andy Woodward</a> that opened all this up and for a while I carried on pretending it hadn’t happened to me. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/22/steve-walters-andy-woodward-crewe-alexandra">Steve Walters, another of my old Crewe mates, was next</a> and, though it hit me like a ton of bricks, I still couldn’t bring myself to admit straight away I was another one. It’s only now, after an awful lot of soul-searching, that I feel strong enough to do it. But it’s tough, really tough. It isn’t easy admitting you were one of Barry Bennell’s boys.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/crewe-barry-bennell-micky-fallon">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/football">Football</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/crewealexandra">Crewe Alexandra</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uk">UK news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/sport">Sport</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/barry-bennell">Barry Bennell</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 12:00:46 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>Seasonal jobs: athletes competing at Summer and Winter Olympics</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/16/seasonal-jobs-athletes-competing-at-summer-and-winter-olympics</link>
      <description><p>By competing at Rio 2016 and Pyeongchang 2018, Tonga’s bare-chested flag-bearer joins a select few in Olympic history</p><p>With his shirtless appearances at the opening ceremonies in Rio and Pyeongchang, Tonga’s Pita Taufatofua has become the very public face of athletes who have competed at both the Summer and Winter Olympics. Taufatofua switched his discipline from taekwondo in Brazil in 2016, to cross-country skiing in South Korea this year, joining the rare breed of athletes who have been able to take part in both types of Olympic games. There are just 161 of them in total.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/16/seasonal-jobs-athletes-competing-at-summer-and-winter-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is Rob Gronkowski going to be the next American action hero?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2018/feb/13/rob-gronkowski-nfl-retirementhollywood-acting</link>
      <description><p>The New England Patriots tight end has hinted he may consider retiring at the age of 28 – and there are plenty of reasons for swapping the NFL for Hollywood<br></p><p><br>Following his team’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/04/super-bowl-2018-philadelphia-eagles-new-england-patriots-nfl">Super Bowl loss</a> this month, New England Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski <a href="http://www.syracuse.com/sports/index.ssf/2018/02/rob_gronkowski_retirement_patriots_acting_movies.html">hinted he is contemplating retirement</a>. It’s not entirely certain how seriously the 28-year-old is taking his decision – many believe this is merely <a href="http://patriotswire.usatoday.com/2018/02/07/rob-gronkowskis-retirement-rumors-are-nothing-more-than-contract-leverage/">a contract negotiation stunt</a> – but if he does retire, the NFL’s loss could become Hollywood’s gain.</p><p>Sylvester Stallone and Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, who himself made the leap from wrestling to Hollywood, have been <a href="http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/22368278/actors-encourage-new-england-patriots-te-rob-gronkowski-pursue-movie-career">trying to convince</a> Gronkowski to try his hand at acting, while David Arquette, who apparently is still in the industry, has even <a href="http://www.tmz.com/2018/02/10/david-arquette-rob-gronkowski-acting-career-movies/">offered</a> to produce a feature with him.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2018/feb/13/rob-gronkowski-nfl-retirementhollywood-acting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Champagne on ice: the mystery and myths behind Dutch skating success</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2018/feb/13/debunkin-g-myths-dutch-winter-olympics-speed-skating-success</link>
      <description>Dutch fans take great pleasure in attempts to make sense of their dominance, particularly the frozen-canals theory<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicholas_Tomalin" title="">Nicholas Tomalin</a> reckoned that the three qualities a journalist needs to succeed are rat-like cunning, a plausible manner and a little literary ability, none of which are much use when you’re trying to <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/02/gif-guide-figure-skaters-jumps-olympics/357723/" title="">tell a salchow from a toe-loop</a> on a tight deadline. During the Winter Olympics it pays to be a quick study, too. Particularly in Britain, where the usual recreational activities in winter are football, baking potatoes and having a national freak-out about each smattering of snow. Because the first week of the Games always provokes perplexing questions, like why are the Dutch so <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-europe-26334026/sochi-2014-why-are-dutch-so-good-at-speed-skating" title="">damn good</a> at speed skating?</p><p>As of Monday, the Netherlands had won 117 medals in the Winter Olympics. One was in snowboarding. One was in short track skating. Three were in figure skating. And 111 were in speed skating. In the first three days of this Games the Netherlands won six of the nine speed skating medals available. Which means they’re already halfway to their medal target of 12, and there are nine days of competition still to go. In Sochi in 2014 they won 23 of the sport’s 36 medals, which was reckoned to be the single most dominant performance by a country in any sport, at any Olympics.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2018/feb/13/debunkin-g-myths-dutch-winter-olympics-speed-skating-success">Continue reading...</a></description>
